result.title: A comprehensive guide to Competitive Programming
result.content:
Hi all

If you didn't take part in Practice Contest #1, you can do so now as a virtual contest. The contest is available here. Click on "Virtual Participation" or here to start the contest. If you don't know what virtual contests are, google it!
If you did take part in the contest, but we unable to solve some question during the contest, we recommend you solve it now, even though you were present in the discussion session!

Many of you are new to the world of competitive programming, and thus we recommend you to go through this blog in long term:
Getting Started with Sport Programming
This is an excellent kick-starter resource for competitive programming, but touches a very large amount of topics in detail. You are recommended to go through this lecture at your own pace.

We recommend you to use C++, as it has a lot of inbuilt libraries which will surely help you in the long run. Also, you can write C code in C++ as well, without any issues. You can learn about the Standard Template Library (STL) of C++ from these TopCoder tutorials:
- TopCoder STL Part 1
- TopCoder STL Part 2

Here are the lecture slides we had used in Summer 2016 to teach Competitive Programming:
1. Dynamic Programming, Greedy Algorithms and Number Theory
2. Standard Template Library
3. Graph Theory
4. Graph Theory (Continued) and Problem Solving Techniques

Here is a comprehensive list of data structures and algorithms along with tutorial links.

Many of you haven't joined the Google Group yet, thus I request you to do the same by sending a join request here:
IITK Competitive Programming Google Group
Visit this group regularly for updates.

Hope this should be enough for now!
If you have any doubt, want to discuss some problem or concept, feel free to start a thread on the google group.
